question: In patients with inflammatory eye disease, does systemic immunosuppressive therapy increase cancer-specific mortality compared with no immunosuppressive therapy? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Patients who used azathioprine, methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil, ciclosporin, systemic corticosteroids, or dapsone had overall and cancer mortality similar to that of patients who never took immunosuppressive drugs.
content.source_2: In a propensity score–matched cohort of adults with inflammatory eye disease, systemic immunosuppressant exposure was associated with higher cancer-specific mortality compared with nonusers (adjusted hazard ratio 1.35, 95% CI 1.12–1.62) over a median 7.2-year follow-up.
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Most commonly used immunosuppressive drugs do not seem to increase overall or cancer mortality.
content.source_4: A competing-risks analysis of a nationwide IED registry found a dose-dependent increase in 10-year cancer mortality among patients receiving long-term systemic corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors (6.0% vs 3.1% in untreated controls; subdistribution HR 1.58, 95% CI 1.21–2.05), even after excluding individuals with prior malignancy.
